properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 10 cm of snow is expected this morning. A frontal systems moving across the Gulf of Alaska continues to bring periods of heavy snow to the South Klondike highway near White Pass this morning. Gusty southerly winds combined with snow are producing blowing snow. The heavy snow is expected to ease to a few flurries this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T05:12:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T13:22:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2069158737.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of fronts will bring upwards of 100 mm of rain across the central coast and northern Vancouver Island by Tuesday morning. While warning level rainfall criteria may not be reached, the total rainfall amount may still trigger localised flooding, debris flow or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T04:51:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T12:52:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1546843334.2020
Area: North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locations: Gander and Vicinity and Bonavista North. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snowfall amounts nearing 15 cm are expected by Wednesday morning, with additional accumulations occuring during the day Wednesday. Temperatures will remain near or slightly above zero, so this snow will be wet and heavy. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will develop on Wednesday, but due to the compact nature of the snow, the risk of widespread blowing snow is low. Conditions are expected to improve late in the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T11:23:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T19:24:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1413776179.2020
Area: Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity

properties.Summary:

Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm is expected. The heavy rain will ease by Tuesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense frontal system will move across the BC Coast today and Tuesday. Showers have developed across the region this morning. These showers will continue today and are expected to intensify to heavy rain this evening over Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver, west and central Fraser Valley. Total rainfall accumulation of 60 to 90 mm is expected through Tuesday morning. The heavy rain will ease by midday Tuesday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: 2 to 4 cm. Time span: continuing until early Tuesday morning. Maximum winds: northerly gusting to 60 km/h. Locations: Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Remarks: Conditions will gradually improve through tonight and into early Tuesday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A robust frontal system will bring heavy snow to the Columbia region today into Tuesday. With temperatures below zero and ample moisture, snow will begin this morning over North Columbia and Rogers Pass and intensify to heavy snow this afternoon. For East Columbia and Yoho Park regions, snow will start later this afternoon. Total snowfall accumulation is expected to be 15 to 25 cm. The heavy snow will switch over to rain for North Columbia early Tuesday morning. Heavy snow will ease late Tuesday for Rogers Pass, Yoho Park and East Columbia. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T08:13:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T16:14:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1762834060.2020
Area: North Columbia, Kinbasket, East Columbia, Yoho Park - Kootenay Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Satellite imagery suggests that an area of freezing rain will move into Churchill by late this afternoon. The freezing rain will likely last a couple of hours and is expected to end early this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind and rain likely for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: The Avalon Peninsula. Possible rainfall: 25 to 40+ mm Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas could see gusts approach 100 km/h on Wednesday as winds shift to northwesterly. Remarks: A deep low pressure system will track near the Avalon Peninsula. While it seems likely that precipitation will be mainly rain, the snow-rain line is expected to be near the isthmus. If the track of the low were to shift further southeast, significant snowfall could be possible over the western Avalon. Rainfall warnings are not expected at this point, since the ground is not frozen and there is no snowpack. Under these circumstances, 50 mm of rain in 24 hours would be required for a warning. Conditions will improve by Wednesday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T11:26:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T19:27:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0687793870.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An area of freezing rain is expected to cross extreme Northern Manitoba today. Freezing rain is expected to begin around noon in Tadoule Lake. The freezing rain may be mixed with or change over at times to snow. At least a couple of hours of freezing rain is likely before precipitation ends later today. ### Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T04:19:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T17:50:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3061540399.2020
Area: Tadoule Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Snowfall for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: Eastern half of the Island, excluding the Avalon and Burin peninsulas. Possible snowfall: Generally 10 to 20 cm with potential for higher amounts locally. Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas along the south and east coasts could see gusts approach 100 km/h. Remarks: The cause of this disruption to our lack of winter weather will be a deep low pressure system passing near the Avalon Peninsula. Snow will begin on Tuesday evening and persist in some areas until Wednesday afternoon. Temperatures are expected to be near zero, which means areas along the coast may see the snow mix with or change completely over to rain. Unfortunately, this also means the snow is likely going to be rather wet and heavy. We will also likely see a period of freezing rain and ice pellets over the easternmost regions Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. Extra considerations for the Clarenville area and the Bonavista Peninsula: These areas are expected to be right along the snow-rain line. If the storm track shifts further northwest, precipitation in these areas could easily be mostly rain, with up to 30 mm possible instead of snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T11:25:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T19:26:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3961228102.2020
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A frontal system moving through B.C. will spread strong winds to the B.C. Peace today. Winds are expected to rise to southwest 70 km/h gusting to 90 late this morning. Winds will ease by this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions continue near the Richardson Mountains early this morning. Easterly winds of 70 gusting to 90 km/h near Rock River continue to give near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. The strongest winds are expected to ease this morning bringing an end to blizzard conditions. However, gusty easterly winds will continue near the Richardson Mountains this afternoon and tonight. Local areas of blowing snow with reduced visibility are expected through tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T03:19:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T11:20:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0954294290.2020
Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Winds this afternoon and tonight are slightly diminished from the 120 km/h this morning, however winds gusts to 100 km/h are still likely. On Tuesday, very strong winds are expected to produce wind gusts as high as 120 to 130 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
